I am not a professional reviewer.  I have seen the "Elizabeth R" series on Masterpiece Theatre and also the most recent "Elizabeth" with Cate Blanchett.  They were both excellent in their way and genre.  Robert Hardy played the Earl of Leceister in the original "Elizabeth R" and Thomas Hardy plays the same role in "The Virgin Queen".  I don't think they are related.  I did not expect to like this series.  Now I LOVE it.  First of all, Elizabeth was barely 25 years old when she ascended the throne.  And she knew Robert Dudley as a child.  He was proclaimed one of the handsomest men in England.  When you watch this movie you realize that for all her great intelligence and advanced book learning, she was a young and impressionable woman.  Watch them dance in front of the Archduke's ambassador in part one.  The music and the way they look at one another, it pulls your heart.  Imagine spending the formative years of your life under threat of a perpetual death sentence only to become not only FREE but top of the heap so to speak.  Watch when they come to tell her she is Queen.  The music and the look on her face.  When she runs to the tree outside of Hatfield house.  The music alone makes this series memorable.  See this as a slice of true life.  When I was 25 years old my aunt called me a "kid".  When I see photos of that time, I realize what she meant now. Her court at her accession were a very young group of people.  Sadly she outlived most of peers and was later surrounded by those who did not know her as a young and vibrant queen.  Enjoy this series.  And this actress does a fantastic older queen as well.  Especially when she "forgives that fart" of one of her courtiers in her old age.  What really happened was he bowed to her at one point and a massive FART slipped out.  He left the country and traveled for SEVEN years.  When he returned and was presented again at court one of the first things she said was "I had forgot that fart".

I always like the PBS Masterpiece Theatre series because they make sure that they do a good job with their movies. I'm not someone who likes movies made for tv because most of them are pretty poor, but not those by PBS, and I loved this movie. I think that it depicted Queen Elizabeth I, pretty well.

The movie starts with Elizabeth being locked up in the tower with her two friends, Kat and Lettice. Elizabeth's sister Queen Mary I sees her as a threat but doesn't want to execute her and locks her up in the tower. Elizabeth of course is worried for her future but when her sister dies of a tumor, then she is elected to be queen. Thus begins the reign of the Virgin Queen and the Elizabethan era, her affair with the married Robert Dudley and her desire to remain single and not be ruled over by a man. Its difficult to pin down Elizabeth because she isn't a one dimensional character, she was a most complex person.

She had a temper, liked to swear, and other such things. She wasn't perfect, history tells us this and the PBS series depicts that. Anne-Marie Duff does a wonderful job as Queen Elizabeth I and she looks so much like her. Tom Hardy is quite sexy as Robert Dudley, but I was quite confused because he wore an earring and gentlemen back in the day didn't wear them. I would give this movie five stars but I got a little confused about politics towards the second half of the movie.

Anyhow, the whole cast did a fantastic job with their characters. The costumes are gorgeous and the sets are wonderful as well, I've never seen the Cate Blanchett movie because its rated R and I don't want to see any gruesome things and thus this is a perfect movie to learn about Elizabeth and what she was all about.

I watched this recently on PBS with high hopes of learning more about England's Gloriana, Elizabeth I. Instead what I got was a cocquettish performance by Anne-Marie Duff who choses to portray Elizabeth as a shrewish brat who seems to be thinking with her groin instead of her head. The film focuses on her relationships with Robert Dudley and with Dudley's stepson, Robert Devereaux. This Elizabeth flirts, and screams in tantrums, but shows little of the diplomacy and finesse that the real Elizabeth had. While it's certainly a very pretty film to look at in terms of costume and settings, the portrayals of Elizabeth by Glenda Jackson (still the best!), Cate Blanchett and Bette Davis still are far better than this trivial tripe.

Overall, I thought this is one of the better Elizabeth films. True, its no "Elizabeth R" but that mini-series was able to do so much more because of its length. Duff really looks like Elizabeth and I liked that they did play off of the queen's vanity and insecurities about her body. I teach British Literature to undergraduates and I'm hoping this film will help give them a little more understanding of the era. Yes, its been modernized. Yes, its portrayal of Amy Robsart's death irked me. Yes, "Elizabeth R" is better. But in a classroom with students who maybe saw the Cate Blancett film, I think it will be useful.

Just as a film, it is beautiful, well acted and engaging. The sound track is particularly effective.

Tudor enthusiasts, such as myself, will obviously make comparisons of this series to the Holy Grail of Elizabeth portrayals - that being Glenda Jackson in the 1970's Masterpiece Theatre mini-series "Elizabeth R".  Anne Marie Duff is no  Glenda Jackson.  I think she made for a more subdued Elizabeth, especially in part I of this mini-series.  "Elizabeth R" is also a much longer mini-series (9 hours) so it delves more deeply into historical occurrences.

I was constantly distracted by Duff's middle-class English accent, but I am a purist - just call me stuffy.  Fortunately, most people will not notice this, especially in the United States.  One favorable factor for Duff is that I happen to think she resembles Elizabeth more than any other actress that has ever portrayed the Queen.  If you look at the famous unfinished miniature of Elizabeth by Isaac Oliver, a portrait that experts regard as a very authentic likeness, Anne Marie Duff is a dead-on resemblance (which is probably a major factor in her obtaining this part).

As for the acting, much of the language has been modernized and not as true to the authentic speeches and quotes from the Queen. "Elizabeth R" is more authentic in this regard.  The costumes and sets were probably the major stars of this film.  I did admire the fact that they didn't throw her in bed with Robert Dudley (Elizabeth's great love) as they do in my most portrayals.  Also, most speculative occurrences, like how Amy Robsart died (suicide, accident or murder)  or Mary, Queen of Scott's coded letters of treason, are given artistic license;  the script writers freely provide their own version of what actually happened, ignoring historical fact.

In conclusion, I think it did a fine job showing the Queen to be the strong and brave woman devoted to her Kingdom and people that she undoubtedly was. This is an admirable presentation, and a far better and more authentic portrayal than Shekkar Kapur's disaster "Elizabeth" with Cate Blanchett.  Although loved by many, Kapur's "Elizabeth" is widely regarded as historical garbage and detested by most Tudor enthusiasts.

This is a very interesting programme, produced in Britain and originally shown on the PBS series, Masterpiece Theatre.

This miniseries was directed by Coky Giedroyc, a veteran of television productions in Britain, including another royal-themed miniseries, 'William and Mary', in 2003.  Giedroyc brings an interesting modern twist to the series - rather than filming things in majestic, sweeping camera pans with classical music as a background, and rather than having the dialogue (and acting) be in a stilted, falsely formal style, Giedroyc incorporates modern music with medieval and Celtic flavouring to it (both of which have experienced a renaissance of sorts in the past decade), and the situations are decidedly modern without being out of place in their own times.

This presents the life of Elizabeth from her young adulthood under Queen Mary, as a supposed participant in intrigues against the Catholic Queen, through to her death after serving decades on the throne of England as the Virgin Queen, the queen who never married.  In fact, the miniseries plays a tantalising game with Elizabeth's virginity, showing her desires (as well as those around her) without ever giving up the game of 'was she or wasn't she?'  Anne-Marie Duff  plays the part of Elizabeth, and does a remarkably able job for such a complex figure.  Duff won the Irish Television award and was nominated for the BAFTA award for best actress in a television drama in another series, 'Shameless', last year.

Duff is joined by Tom Hardy, who plays the role of Robert Dudley, the favourite of Queen Elizabeth.  Dudley is also an extraordinarily complex role, as he played several sides in the political struggles during Elizabeth's early reign, and was part of a family well experienced in regal intrigue - Robert Dudley's family had tried to manage the reign of Elizabeth's brother Edward, engineer the accession of Lady Jane Grey (placing Guildford Dudley on the throne with her), and is sometimes referred to as 'the uncrowned kings of England'.  In fact, perhaps the most stunning single scene in this miniseries is after Elizabeth has elevated Robert Dudley to the earldom of Leicester, and during her illness, he sits upon the throne as the protector of the realm.  Hardy is well suited to this role, and plays it with skill.

The sets are appropriate to their time period, neither too ornate nor too medieval; the costumes also have a touch of modernity to them, but are still primarily of the period.  The situations presented give good insight into the overall pattern of Elizabeth's reign and some of the principal concerns during that time period, although to compress such a long reign into such a short time frame as a four-hour miniseries by necessity means that the history has had to be selectively chosen.  Elizabeth faced problems from without and within, many of which were far more complex and pressing than her marriage issue.  In the end, Elizabeth made the right decision for the time, if not for the future.

This is a great production for television, and holds up well against other major productions featuring the Virgin Queen Elizabeth of a few years ago.

Masterpiece Theatre's 2-part "Elizabeth I - The Virgin Queen" has a lot going for it. Enough, in fact, that it generally succeeds as an engaging historical drama. Anne-Marie Duff gives a laudable lead performance as the titular monarch, supported by an able cast which includes the likes of Joanne Whalley, Tara Fitzgerald and Emilia Fox even in relatively brief roles. The emphasis is on Elizabeth as a flesh-and-blood woman, and the key close relationships of her reign  first and foremost her decades-long untenable passion for Robert Dudley, played by Tom Hardy, whose unaffected studliness fills the bill nicely.

The film is blemished by the distractions of a few minor details (e.g., the graying fake moustache affixed to Hardy late in the action, which appears to have been procured at the 99-cent store) and one not-minor one: the cinematography. Credited to the curiously surnamed David Odd, the camera's proximity to its subjects suggests that perhaps Mr. Odd took a conceptual intention to make an "intimate" film far too literally. For relatively contained interior scenes the strategy works well enough, even if it does lead to the odd curious bit of visual framing. The full shortcomings of the "nothing-wider-than-a-two-shot" choice are most glaring in scenes with any appreciable amount of physical action, e.g., a duel with swords, a tennis match, an insurrection in the streets, etc. In such sequences the camera jostles dizzyingly about, and no momentary focus on an individual is without a quick cut. If the intention was to position the viewer "right in the middle of the action," no mind was paid that cinematically, a little of that effect goes a long way. More than a little of it simply leaves the viewer wondering what the hell is going on, and why he or she can't get a good look at it.

If you watch "The Virgin Queen," do so for the performance of Anne-Marie Duff. She achieves a fully-realized dramatic portrait of an Elizabeth whose 40-year reign was a continuous struggle to assert and maintain political authority, at the cost of any chance of romantic fulfillment. If your desire is a historical epic on a scale larger than one individual, though, you would be best advised to look elsewhere.

The story of Good Queen Bess has been produced more times than I can remember, her non affair with Robert Dudley  Her battles with Mary Queen of Scots which led to the  Scots Queens execution. He decision not to marry and to carry the weight of the realm on her shoulders and her patronage of Dudley's step son The Duke of Essex. Which led to an ill conceived attempt to take the crown from her have been well documented cinematicaly. What makes this production stand out are the performances of Anne Marie Duff ( Late of Shameless) and Tom Hardy ( Legends, Mad Max) There's is an awkward chemistry as she keeps him at bay sexually, while allowing him to dream of a place in her bed. She is mercurial with her affections and banishes him almost in every scene, yet her reliance on him for emotional support continues to grow. Hardy's Dudley is himself a man of moods melancholy and entitled being just a few. Duff gives Elizabeth a solid self reliance as it becomes apparent she will have to fight tooth and nail to be considered 'more than a mere woman'. The production is beautifully staged and the ensemble surrounding the leads give excellent support . In the second part we see an older Elizabeth who in later life no longer commands the respect of her courtiers. Illustrated by two giggling ladies in waiting who go through her personal effects and openly mock her slightly mad dancing. The loss of Dudley and her oldest adviser Henry Cecil, bring her to this low point. She is humiliated in her chamber by Essex. And we see a rapid decline in her health. Duff makes the transition from young to old with the help of incredible make up and she carries the older Bess with a weariness that 40 years on the throne have bestowed on her. All in all a very satisfying viewing experience

Monarchy, of course, is inferior egovernment, but as for that, Elizabethh the First of England stands out as the greatest autocrat. Extremely educated, highly intelligent, spirited, musical, talented, shrewd, and dedicated and loyal to her loved people, England, and peace.
She did not seek to control people's religion, and she insisted on a 'balanced budget' as it were. She had the good setnse to suround herself with competent and trustworthy advisors of the caliber of Wiliam Cecil and Francis Walsingham. She inspired greatness in the likes of writers Ben Jonson and William Shakespeare, a sailor in the person of Francis Drake, who served her well most especially in England's defense against the invading Spanish Armada in 1588. Elizabeth traveled to the coast to stand before her troops during that siege. She spoke thusly: "I know I have the body of a weak and feeble woman, but I have the heart and stomach of a king, and of a king of England too."

This is a story that bears telling over and over again, and I applaud that effort.

Anne-Marie Duff and Tom Hardy both give excellent performances, but the effect is spoiled somewhat by the insane camera work and musical score. Even for a BBC production, the camera work on this miniseries is awful. It looks like it was shot on an unsteady handheld camcorder with digital zoom. The shots are always held close to the actors faces, with their hands or other actors' noses haphazardly intruding in the frame. After a few hours of this, I really wished I could see the rest of them, because I felt like it really cut off their gestures as part of their performance. The soundtrack is twinkly post-rock guitar music. I have no idea why. It's terrible.
Other than that, the costumes and sets are great. I give the production huge credit for not putting Tom Hardy in some terrible wig like he's been forced to wear in almost every other period piece he's in. The focus on vanity and repressed sexual desire as a main driving force in Elizabeth's reign got a little old after a while. Couldn't the writers have found at least some drama in the way such an extraordinary woman dealt with the political struggles of her time?

I am writing this review as someone who enjoys history but is not an expert in the subject.  I have a fascination for period pieces which leads me to watch most films of various eras- I like to compare them to one another and see the various perspectives.  That, more than history books, helps me to understand the complexities of what actually happened and who ended up 'writing history'.  As we all know, whomever wrote the history books got to tell only their viewpoint.  What actually happened may never be known to anyone but those who actually lived during those years.  I liked this film because it didn't over glamorize Elizabeth's beauty- neither did it over glamorize Mary, Queen of Scotts, for that matter.  I also liked that it showed more of her history than her ascension to the throne.  Most movies seem to focus on only her youth.  I didn't realize that Dudley continued to be a close advisor to her in her later reign.  Or, is that creative license?  I found it interesting how they interpreted her as using Dudley's affection as a way to keep her suitors at arms distance and found him to be a threat once he became single- I had never heard that interpretation before.  I had also not heard that she might have supported Robert Devereux which such high favor because she might have thought him to be the son of Robert Dudley.  That was interesting.  On a humorous note, I found the tooth pulling scene to be hilarious.  In any case, I found the make up, costumes, set and overall filmmaking to be of the highest quality and truly enjoyed this movie throughout.  I was completely horrified by Elizabeth's teeth as an older woman and can only hope that it was not as bad as all that.  I hope that was not a bow to English stereotypes.  So why only four stars and not five?  I don't know.  I reserve five stars for those movies that take me to the next level in emotion.  This one, for all its great quality, didn't do that.  I enjoyed it, but it didn't move me.  Thus, the four stars.

This drama based on the life of Elizabeth I focuses on her liaison with Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, and his stepson Robert, Earl of Essex. Though not precisely historical, the miniseries is attractively filmed, and the lead Anne-Marie Duff plays Elizabeth to the hilt, from young princess to aging and sour-faced queen. The famous speech at Tilbury seems to be a requisite of any life of Elizabeth, and it's here, on the eve of her victory over the Spanish Armada (mostly helped by a titanic storm) but the military intrigues are often off-screen. It's the intrigue to keep her or get her off the throne that takes center stage.

Tom Hardy plays an excellent Robert Dudley and he's aged from beautiful youth to tired middle-aged or almost-middle aged man well by some terrific make up artistry. The costuming is equally beautiful, often focusing on the jewels rather than the "twenty pounds of gorgeousness" as I heard someone once describe Tudor costume.

The music is a mix of chanting by Bulgarian women's choirs (that sound is unmistakable and haunting), new compositions by Martin Phipps and Latin chanting by the Mediaeval Baebes. It's stunning music, sad that the soundtrack is not available except at ridiculous asking prices. It really adds to the drama. While not "Elizabeth R" with Glenda Jackson, it's well worth seeing and quite enjoyable.

Elizabeth I - The Virgin Queen is the first cinematic (or literary) account of Queen Bess's life that convinced me I should care about her.  I've never liked her.  Admired her accomplishments, her confidence, her intelligence, her savvy and street-smarts, maybe, but...like her?  No.  And yet, here, in an entirely un-retouched portrait of the woman, I finally found a human being I could understand and...maybe not quite like, but certainly care about and root for.  Plus, the film is just so darn well done.  I just couldn't bear to finish watching it, and I'll tell you why, but first...

This film has an authentic period sensibility that succeeds at rendering the characters humanly sympathetic to a modern audience, without resorting to anachronisms to do so.  Costumes, settings, language, situations, and the values of the characters are all in keeping with their time and place.  This Elizabeth biopic is more than satisfying from a historical angle.

From a purely story point of view, this telling of the Virgin Queen's life is as full of hooks as a blackberry bramble.  Almost from the first shot, you see characters' motives and goals on a collision-course with their circumstances and with other characters.  In short order the writing, directing, and performances create characters whose collisions are going to matter to you.  Maybe even a lot.

And that's the problem with Really Good Historical Cinema, and why I didn't finish watching Masterpiece's : Elizabeth I.  Having read a great deal of English history, I know exactly how each of these characters' stories turned out, and no matter how hard I hoped, the story wouldn't change, because it's history: -------'s life was still going to end messily, and -------'s romance was going to lead to his downfall, etc.  I just couldn't bear to watch, once this film had got its hooks in me and made me care about them as people.  Doesn't mean you shouldn't, though!

I very much enjoyed this film, and though it was definitely on a par with Elizabeth The Golden Age, but with a very different focus.
The narrative traces Elizabeth's imprisonment by her sister Mary, Mary's death and her enthronement, through her tempestuous relationship with Robert Dudley (played consummately by Tom Hardy, portrayed as a very self-centered and arrogant man) and the emergence of Mary Queen of Scots as a rival, though unlike The Golden Age, where Mary plays a large role, in this version she is never actually shown, only discussed. A lot of the events are portrayed in discussion or letters as is the death of Dudley and the defeat of the Spanish Armada, though a stirring recreation of Elizabeth's speech to the troops at Tilbury is a highlight of the film. The film does well in it's use of real quotes together with more modern usage of conversation. Great costumes and scenery

The death of Amy Robsart (Emila Fox) , Dudley's wife is portrayed as s suicide, though one that Dudley reacts callously to and the Elizabeth's rivalry with Lettice Knollys (Sienna Gillory) is part of the focus.
The last part deals with Elizabeth devotion to the young Robert Devereaux (Hans Mattheson) , Earlf of Essex, and frames Essex plot against Elizabeth as being intigated by his mother Lettice.
Anne Marie Duff portrays Elizabeth quite expertly. Effortlessly playing the role of a young Elizabeth through to her aging and death. Elizabeth is revealed as wise, strong, devoted to her country and people, at times capricious and ruthless when necessary. Her anguish at being forced to sign the death warrant of Mary Queen of Scots is revealed in a dream of herself being executed in Mary's place. Quite a lot of her life  is revealed in this film in dreams, such as her desire for Robin Dudleywhere she dreams of making love to him. Great speech near the end before her court summing up her feeling about her life and reign.

The second half of this movie is much easier to follow for those viewers who have no background in the many 'Wives of Henry VIII'. You see the dangerous world faced by Henry's two daughters after their father, King Henry VIII, and their younger brother, Edward, the Prince of Wales, are both dead. This telling of the life of Elizabeth I from young woman to the end of her reign and death is one of the most vibrant versions I have seen. This Elizabeth is intelligent, cunning, and charismatic, but also vain, love-struck, and petulant. Paula Milne wrote an exceptional screenplay for this production.

As a young woman who is basically held as a prisoner by her sister, Queen Mary, she is well aware of the court intrigues that she must navigate or risk death. She must pretend that she is loyal to her sister and that she embraces her views that Catholicism should be the one religion for England. But in her heart is still a protestant, but sees that religious freedom for her people is more important than punishment. She is also a young woman with desires and a lust for living.  Her love of Robert Dudley, a childhood friend, seems almost obsessive, but the scene of them riding together on the horse after she's ascended the throne is one of a carefree, laughing young Elizabeth -- you feel her joy and love.

As queen, you realize she is her father's daughter because this Elizabeth is a strong leader and brooks no challenge to her authority and lets them know she is a woman, but a determined and extremely capable ruler and politician. It is her weakness as a woman craving love from Robert Dudley and then Robert Devereaux that makes her more vulnerable. She cares for her people in war and shows her willingness to be amongst them, and that makes her popular with her people. She is first and foremost a queen.

At the end of her life you feel as if you have really seen a truly great queen, but you also are left wondering could her life have been different as you remember the young, laughing Elizabeth and see the ravaged body and mind of Elizabeth on her deathbed.

The Mediaeval Baebes provide some truly wonderful vocals that underscore the beauty of the music and the feeling that this story of Elizabeth is more contemporary than not.

How many Elizabeths have we been offered so far? Very few are memorable and Masterpiece Theater has proved the best by far. All this is believably played out by Anne-Marie Duff and Tom Hardy to this viewer's delight.

With the exception of the wonderful Helen Mirren who deservedly won best actress for her Elizabeth I in the very fine HBO production, all other Elizabeths pale and fade away.  Cate Blanchet is a beautiful and brilliant actress but she could not save, for me at least, the over-acclaimed versions of Elizabeth and Elizabeth-The Golden Age despite gorgeous cinematography and production values. The story line was ridiculous and historically unworthy--Anjou a drag queen? Lettice Knolles was not murdered by a poisoned gown, she actually married Robert Dudley and, I believe, outlived him!  And Walsingham, who did pursue and achieve the conviction of Mary Stuart,  a hands-on regicide?

In the past 5 years or so I've watched close to 8 to 10 films about Elizabeth I. I've always been fascinated by the Tudors & their tumultuous times. Like other history fans, I have my favorite characters--and villains. Fortunately, Elizabeth is on the favorites list (AND Mary, Queen of Scots--figure that one out.). After watching a number of extremely brilliant women actors in the role, I thought it was getting a bit ridiculous to see an English Queen running around telling just about everybody, "I'm a Virgin, I'm a Virgin, I'm a Virgin!" Good grief--shades of The Material Girl! Well, of course there was a good reason for that. I think most historians agree that Elizabeth skillfully allied her political reputation to the high level of adoration the people of the period (even Protestants) felt for the Blessed Virgin Mary. Then there's the practical reality that being virgo intacta was vital to be a player in the European monarchial marriage game. This too Elizabeth played to her advantage. By keeping kings & countries waiting & guessing on her next move, Elizabeth felt relatively safe and--perhaps more importantly, on the strictly personal level--garnered her the verbal romantic attention she seemed to obsessively crave. Coky Giedroyc, director of this production stated, "Elizabeth had...a real pathological fear of intimacy. Her father (Henry VIII) represented everything male, and once you get close to a man you get killed..." She also had her mother's fate to reflect on. Even a naughty queen can lose her head--especially if her hubby was good ol' Henry (a Tudor definitely NOT on my favorites list--but his cast-off wife Katherine of Aragon is.) Elizabeth was considered an "enlightened" queen, even an intellectual (in an age when it was considered very suspicious for a woman to have ideas of her own.) Nonetheless, she was a child of her violent time, and was not adverse to employing torture & deception in her struggle to keep her throne. Still, she was better than most of her contemporaries and she clearly possessed a highly tuned conscience. I'd never seen Anne-Marie Duff before. Hers is not the tall, killer blonde type; but rather she is short, elfin, with flowing, strawberry blonde hair (at least in this film.) And she possess an inner charm, a real charisma and intellectual radiance. She is perfect for the role of Elizabeth. She appears to effortless generate regal majesty, and that is as much matter of personal character as it is of acting skill. There are three scenes from the film that stand in my mind. The first was the opening (a good omen of enjoyment to come.) A teenage Elizabeth has been banished to The Tower by her bitter, paranoid half-sister, Mary. She is talking with ladies-in-waiting, when they hear soldiers approaching. They scramble to set a scene of humble piety by hiding things & "straightening up." One of the ladies tosses a rosary like a football to Elizabeth, who catches it in mid-air. The second scene is not far from the first. Mary has died & Elizabeth becomes the new Queen. She is in a triumphal procession weaving through the streets London. Here Anne-Marie Duff is at her most radiant, showering the people with her gratitude & basking in the love they had for her. It's ironic that the common folk loved Elizabeth almost in proportion to how much they hated her mother (Anne Boleyn.) In a similar sort of twist, the people disliked Queen Mary (Tudor) as much as they loved her mother, the divorced Queen Katherine The third scene is near the end of the picture. Elizabeth is old & near the end of her days. She is standing at the end of a large outdoor court while her new, very young ladies-in-waiting stand at the opposite end surreptitiously watching her. Elizabeth is so caught up thinking about the past that she seems unaware of their critical stare. In her mind she hears a song from her bygone youth, and begins to rather awkwardly--and feebly--dance to the tune. To the maids she's an object of ridicule & they parody her movements in a dance they find hopeless old fashioned. It is a poignant scene reflecting the relentless nature of time & the cruel honesty of youth--and it reminds us that, in the end, Elizabeth was a vulnerable human being too. Another aspect I appreciate about this "Elizabeth," is that it was mercifully brief & fairly neutral in the depiction of the rivalry between Elizabeth Tudor & her cousin, Mary Queen of Scots. British films have almost invariably portrayed Mary Stuart as either an idiot, or a sex-driven demon out to bring the Inquisition into England. Neither is true, but there's little doubt that had Mary ascended to the English crown, it would have been a full-blown disaster for all concerned. The supporting cast & essential production values are of the highest quality. A special nod to the music (see CD review below) and costumes (people, including men, really knew how to dress in those days!) Anne of the Thousand Days / Mary, Queen of Scots Elizabeth I: The Virgin Queen

This is a fantastic interpretation of the lives of the Virgin Queen and her court. Masterpiece Theatre and all involved have outdone themselves here. Along with the movie itself, the music is wonderfully enchanting and matched perfectly to the film! Prepare to be swept away!

What a beautiful love story, I had no idea,...and how painful that had to have been for her, to forego marriage because she couldn't wed her truest love. She was quite a woman indeed! Well documented and the music was fantastic!

I have three films on Queen Elizabeth I in my library and this is by far the best in my collection.  I have not see the one with Glenda Jackson to date and it is on my Wish List.

First off, I found the use of language to be intelligent, not like the Hollywood Elizabeth that seems to lack true English wit.  I am caught up every time I watch this with the casting, scenery, and costumes, which in turn merely embellishs the script.  Some reviewers mentioned that this production left out Queen Elizabeth's other accomplishments by focusing on her relationships.  Quite the contrary, I found it just as intriguing due the fact that it showed the human side upon which every leader or monarch has had to endure.  This film showed the "frail feminine side and the body politic" Queen Elizabeth struggled so hard to balance, a difficult feat for anyone.  It is mentioned in the history books that as she got older she suffered terrible headaches likely due to immense stress. I see there is nothing wrong with highlighting this part of her life, if so however accurate or inaccurate it is nothing but captivating performances, strong content, and true human emotion.

Tom Hardy's performance in this film has made me a fan of his and will continue to look for other works of his.  His character as the Earl of Leicester seamlessly transitions from a young suitor to an older, wiser man faithfully standing by the queen's side until the day of his death.  Duff's performance of the Queen encapsulated her joy's, frustrations, struggles, love and loss spot on. You will not be disappointed.  It is not often for me to be so taken in with a movie that I forget I am watching a film on a 15" laptop.

I found the modernized soundtrack and fast-cut video editing to be distracting and offputting. Many of the characters frankly looked too "modern" to be believable, particularly Tom Hardy who would have been more suited to a street gang film.

Production values, of course, were high and lent the film a sumptious air but it ended up being little more than eye candy.

I've seen so many other, better, Elizabeths, that I cannot recommend this one. Obviously, I'm in the minority, but that's nothing new for me. I have, let us say, oddball tastes!
The movie provided insight into life of the Queen Elizabeth I and heighten my curiosity into her life.

I very much enjoyed the beginning and end of this production; the period preceding and following Elizabeth's inheriting her crown were very well acted and gave a good sense of what her character would be like.  The middle, however, was dragged down by dwelling too much on her relationships with Leicester and her various suitors, making her seem very bland and uninteresting.

My favorite part of the production was the last hour or so, portraying her as an aging woman trying to keep up the fantasy of the invincible queen. This 2005 BBC miniseries "The Virgin Queen" follows the life of Queen Elizabeth I (Anne-Marie Duff) from her confinement by half-sister Queen Mary on suspicion of treason, through Elizabeth's ascendancy to the throne of England at age 25, to the end of her 44-year reign as England's never-married "virgin queen". The aesthetic is generally dark, as most of the film takes places in dimly lit, unwelcoming interiors that contrast with the Queen's dazzling wardrobe. "The Virgin Queen" is more historically accurate than the 1998 feature film "Elizabeth" that starred Cate Blanchett, but this production places more emphasis on Queen Elizabeth's personal life than on her political accomplishments. Particular attention is paid to her resistance to marriage in the face of many suitors, her affectionate relationship with Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester (Tom Hardy), and with her ill-fated protg Robert Devereux, Earl of Essex (Hans Matheson) late in life.

American and British audiences will undoubtedly view "The Virgin Queen" differently and quarrel with different points. I presume that Brits will be more rigorous with historical accuracy, the interpretation of the Queen Elizabeth's personality, and inconsistencies in the accents. Americans are more likely to simply have trouble following the events, because the film skips large periods of time. If viewers are not familiar with the history, they will have no idea how much time has actually passed. Mary Queen of Scots was confined for 18 years, but, if you didn't know that, you might get the impression that it was only a few months. The make-up department runs away with the show as it progresses. They did a spectacular job of aging the actors. I've never seen such realistic and thorough aging make-up before. Perhaps the make-up and costumes outshine a mediocre script, but I enjoyed looking at them, and I was impressed by Anne-Marie Duff's portrayal of the aged Queen in the last years of her reign.

Filming the story of Gloriana is a virtual guarantee of success for a production studio, from Warner Brothers to BBC. The Virgin Queen still retains her power to enthrall, intrigue and mystify these 500 years after she came to the throne. She was perhaps England's last true absolute monarch, and certainly one of its greatest, if not most famous.

Since the advent of film, she has been one of the most coveted roles to play. Indeed, few monarchs have been so closely chronicled, save perhaps her own father, Henry VIII, and Victoria.

She has been portrayed by some of the most brilliant actresses: Sarah Bernhardt, Bette Davis, Judi Dench, Judith Anderson, Miranda Richardson, Flora Robson, Cate Blanchett, Helen Mirren, even Quentin Crisp, and most famously, and importantly, Glenda Jackson.

And it must be said without doubt that Glenda Jackson's "Elizabeth R" is the defining portrait-- the most accomplished, historically accurate, and masterfully acted. Glenda Jackson is Elizabeth I reincarnate; there is simply none better, and likely never will be.

So now we have Anne-Marie Duff in the red wig for 230 Masterpiece Theatre minutes. Perhaps for the sake of revisionists, we are offered a far less imperious monarch, one who is both reactive (the real one was) and passive (the real one was not). Duff is an odd choice. No beauty like Cate Blanchett, but Elizabeth was known for vanity, not beauty. Duff's Elizabeth, with quivering lip and watercolor behavior, seems filmed underwater, and make for an undesirable monarch-- certainly not the Gloriana of myth or fact. Where is her famous wit, her coy manipulations, her strong moral fiber, her intense devotion to state and loyal courtiers? Left with Glenda Jackson, I suppose. This Elizabeth is a simpering, love-struck maiden or a crass, 60-something hag (and only then do we see bits of fire in the performance). Hag works; crass manages; simpering loses the whole impact.

A suavely elegant, very attractive and distinctly healthy Queen Mary I opens Elizabeth's story (no Catharine Parr, no Thomas Seymour, no childhood) but is quickly dispatched. Just as well, for she's thoroughly ill-cast--Mary was none of those things. (Far better was the wonderful Kathy Burke in the Blanchett version, though she was a bit of a Protestant caricature). Daphne Slater in the Jackson series was far more appealing, and perfectly written.

Elizabeth's transition from prisoner to crown is possibly the greatest story of her long life. No part of her history defines and creates her personality more than these years-- the abuse by Seymour, imprisonment, exile, and finally her accession. Unfortunately, much of this key period is sped through. The fatal flaw in the series is the decision to cast Elizabeth mooning incessantly over Robert Dudley, later Earl of Leicester, here played by a childish, petulant Tom Hardy. There is no chemistry here; he is pretty, but vacant. Glenda Jackson's Dudley, Robert Hardy (no relation that I know of), is a bit of a fop, but he knows his place in court and Elizabeth's heart. Their chemistry is clear. This version of Dudley is a bit ridiculous-- how he would claim the Queen's heart for more than 30 years is a mystery in this performance. So is most of the casting (what's with the acrobat?)

An egregious error in this production is the portrayal of suicide by Dudley's long-suffering wife Amy Robsart, whose death at 26 in 1560 remains to this day a mystery. More time should have been spent on the wooing of Elizabeth by the French Duc d'Alencon, who very nearly came to be her husband (again, the 1971 Glenda Jackson version handles this segment masterfully).

All too soon and without sufficient explanation, we become immersed in the historically key, decades-long battle of wills and imprisonment of the impetuous Mary, Queen of Scots-- Elizabeth's 2nd cousin, granddaughter of Henry VIII's older sister Margaret, whose claim to the English throne made her a rallying point of Catholics, and a very real threat to Elizabeth (it was Mary's son James who succeeded Elizabeth in 1603, founding the ill-fated House of Stuart).

Far more attention should have been paid to the case for and subsequent execution of Mary, Queen of Scots, which was Elizabeth's darkest hour-- forever bloodying her saintly propaganda. Likewise, more attention should have been given to Walshingham, Elizabeth's master of subversion, although William Cecil, Lord Burghley, is given fair due.

The decisive Armada happens much too quickly, lessening its impact and giving far too much time to be spent on the stormy relationship of Elizabeth and Robert Devereaux, Earl of Essex, portrayed by Hans Matheson, who is cast and directed as a bad-tempered, bipolar "Mama's Boy" (a very strange Oedipal twist here) whose hair, look and even attire speak far more to 2005 than 1585. The entire second half of the production is brought down by this admittedly strange relationship, here given a basketful of psychological issues left to the viewer to consider unraveling. The casting is awful, the acting mediocre, the personality baffling. This Essex is a wreck-- blame the revisionist director.

Two significant annoyances: Elizabeth's (Duff's) accent isn't simply London middle-class, which would be fine, but stands in stark contrast to everyone else's appropriate English diction and clarity. She comes off as a guttersnipe. And worse of all-- distracting to the utmost-- is the incessant soundtrack that dominates--and not pleasantly-- the action and plot of the movie. The sheer volume of it is horrendous, to say nothing of the attempts at mixing courtly historical period music with Essex's electric guitar.

My suggestion here is to rent this one, watch it as long as you can, and then return to Davis, Blanchett, Jackson, or even Dench. Overall, a disappointment. Were it not for 95% historical accuracy and enjoyable period costumes-- plus the decent acting (most of the problems are the director's fault, don't blame the actors), it would have earned one star. But this Queen is no legend, and this cast is horrendous. An inglorious Gloriana.

This production has a lot going for it.  Anne-Marie Duff makes a great Elizabeth, and she is supported by an equally talented cast.  The sets, lighting, costuming and direction are good, and the makeup artists did a terrific job of aging Duff as the movie progressed.  I occasionally found the music too much; it sometimes seemed loud and overwhelmed the action, but overall I enjoyed it.

The catch is that the concept of the movie works better in theory than it does in practice.  The Virgin Queen, as the title indicates, focuses on Elizabeth's personal relationships, most specifically her love interests.  To an extent, limiting the program makes sense; Elizabeth was about 69 at her death, and ascended to the throne at 25.  However, over all, Elizabeth's relationships were unusually embarrassing and sad, and to focus on them to the near-exclusion of the other events in her life leaves us with little more than a gossipy, costumed soap opera.  While the events depicted are factual--except where artistic license is used to explain murky aspects--Elizabeth often comes of as a bit trite, and the real queen, for all of her capriciousness, was anything but trite. She saw her kingdom through massive changes, left it stronger than she found it, and was so influential that her reign is still considered a golden age.

There are some genuinely touching moments, and the production is of good quality.  This is a worthwhile purchase, so long as you understand that the focus is very limited.

I know it has a lot of drama and all. But this is not a film for viewers who don't want to hear a Queen Mary with a strong New York accent, see a bunch of people playing Elizabethan roles with decidedly modern movements and speech patterns, and hear rock-y modern music in the background.

I am endlessly fascinated by anything Tudor, and as far as movies on this subject go, this is the best thing available.  It has everything we expect of a Masterpiece Theater production, as far as costumes, sets, and historical accuracy.  This however also has a fantastic dramatic quality. The way things are shot and the way the music is used throughout is stellar, and the entire thing has a very modern feel to it. These are historical figures that we are all familiar with, but they are made very human and relatable here.

Ann Marie Duff is excellent in the role.  I have seen her in several other films and this is her best work. I especially enjoy her in the second half as the aging queen.  It is heartbreaking to see the young members of the court mocking her and being disrespectful to the woman who has given her entire life to thier country. An example of this is when her young ladies in waiting break into her jewel box where she keeps the only things private to her; a portrait of Kat Ashley, and Dudley's last letter.  They also make fun of her dancing: the same dance we see earlier in the film as the popular new dance at court. Ann Marie Duff portrays this complex time of the queens life wonderfully; she is moving.  Another beautiful part is when Elizabeth learns that her sister is dead and she will be queen.  The look on her face as she runs across the field is of pure relief.  She is not as happy about actually becoming queen as she is that her life is less threatened now, and she will be a prisoner no more. The irony is that she is the most powerful woman in the country yet her life is the most strictly governed of all.  Her life is not her own.

I love the music which I think helped to keep the whole thing fresh. I was also happy to see that a makeup artist was finally able to age an actor successfully without making her look like plastic.  If you have enjoyed the Phillippa Gregory books on the Tudors, or the Cate Blanchett movie about Elizabeth, this film will be quite pleasing. It brings the former to life, and expands on the latter.  If you like The Virgin Queen, you might also like The Last King which chronicles the reign of Charles II and also stars Ann Marie Duff.

The costumes were sumptuous, there was more thoughtfulness to keeping historial accuracy, but I have to say that the acting was average. Although I thought Anne Marie Duff looked more like the real Elizabeth I than other portrayals of the queen, her middle class English accent was annoying and unlike what I imagine Elizabeth I really sounded like with her upper class London accent. I actually enjoyed Tom Hardy's portrayal of the seductive "Sweet Robin" more than Anne Marie Duff's portrayal. Her acting was too forced, did not have enough power, and again, the accent was bothersome. My favorite part was the very end, when they discover a hidden compartment in her ring (the real ring resides in a private collection today).

My question is this? When is the woman who was born to play Queen Elizabeth I ever going to do so? If you don't know who I mean, it should be Tilda Swinton. I would give anything to see Tilda Swinton play this part. She is a supreme actor as well as a British aristocrat. She also has the most uncanny resemblence to Elizabeth with her long face and nose, and red hair. For those of who that recently saw Narnia, you will know what I mean.

Until Tilda Swinton plays Elizabeth, Glenda Jackson will always claim the definitive portrayal of Elizabeth I. That record has stood more than 30 years among true Tudor enthusiasts.

As a fan of Queen Elizabeth I, I make it a point to get my hands on every movie, miniseries, program, book, etc that will give me a better insight into this amazing woman.  I can honestly say that Masterpiece Theatre's production of The Virgin Queen is by far the very best I have ever seen.  Elizabeth defined an era and is(in the opinion of this reviewer) one of the stronger female role models in history.  Anne Marie Duff's portrayal was exquisite yet very real because she showed us a passionate, forceful, flawed and misunderstood Queen.  Bravo!
I love this movie, and I enjoyed the soundtrack so much that I have ordered it from the Mediaeval Baebes and listen to it all the time.

I watched this for the 1st time right after watching the wonderful Glenda Jackson's "Elizabeth R". The stories are the same as one would expect from well documented historical dramas.

But these two productions are much different in their flavors. This is a much more human drama. The characters seem more real and are frankly more appealing than in the older drama. The characters in "Elizabeth R" speak as if their words were all scripted by a playwrite, which of course they were. Those in "Elizabeth I - The Virgin Queen" speak and act as real people do... even princes.

My main complaint of this production was the music, which I found shrill and annoying, adding little to the drama. As is so commen these days the music is much too loud relative to the dialogue. One got tired of adjusting the volume.

BBC drama almost always features some of the best acting, writing, design, and cinematography you're likely to find anywhere.  Now Coky Giedroyc's "Elizabeth I: The Virgin Queen" is certainly the best of all the Queen Elizabeth biopics.

Of course, each Elizabeth film's success has always rested on the head of it's leading lady, and the extraordinary Anne-Marie Duff, who has previously played supporting roles in THE MAGDALENE SISTERS and THE WAY WE LIVE NOW, makes the role her own within minutes.  (Great) prosthetics aside, her transformation from youthful radiance to hard-edged seniority is remarkable.

It's true that Duff has an edge over her predecessors; unlike Judi Dench in SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE or Cate Blanchett in ELIZABETH, Duff is given more of the Queen's life to portray, and unlike Glenda Jackson in ELIZABETH R, she isn't saddled with a dry script and a bare-bones production design.  All of those actors gave deservedly lauded performances, and Duff matches them scene-for-scene.  This film is also far more historically accurate than Blanchett's film.

The supporting cast seamlessly blends into the story, including dreamy Tom Hardy and Hans Matheson as the Dudley and Devereux lads, and long-missed (at least in America) Joanne Whalley as Queen Mary.  The swirling score by Martin Phipps is icing on a towering cake.
